solution_01_data_basics/01_counting/07_read_histogram_discrete_v1

video

The first 4 questions involve adding up frequencies of the indicated intervals. The last 4 questions can be done by guessing and checking until something works.


  1. (ANS=29) There are 29 measurements less than 11.5. So, \(\#[\mathbf{x}<11.5]=29\).
  2. (ANS=3) There are 3 measurements more than 10.5. So, \(\#[\mathbf{x}>10.5]=3\).
  3. (ANS=8) There are 8 measurements closer than 1 units from 5.5. So, \(\#[|\mathbf{x}-5.5|<1]=8\).
  4. (ANS=12) There are 12 measurements further than 3 units from 7.5. So, \(\#[|\mathbf{x}-7.5|>3]=12\).
  5. (ANS=10.5) A boundary at \(b=10.5\) has 27 measurements less than it. So, \(\#[\mathbf{x}<10.5]=27\).
  6. (ANS=7.5) A boundary at \(b=7.5\) has 10 measurements more than it. So, \(\#[\mathbf{x}>7.5]=10\).
  7. (ANS=1.5) An interval with radius \(r=1.5\) around center 8 contains 7 measurements. So, \(\#[|\mathbf{x}-8|<1.5]=7\).
  8. (ANS=0.5) An interval with radius \(r=0.5\) around center 9 excludes 26 measurements. So, \(\#[|\mathbf{x}-9|>0.5]=26\).
